recipeInstructions.text: Sift flour, sugar, and salt into a bowl; set aside. Beat eggs and milk together in a large bowl with an electric mixer. Beat in flour mixture until smooth; stir in melted butter.
Lightly grease a griddle or frying pan; heat over medium-high heat.

Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 2 tablespoons for each cr√™pe. Immediately rotate the skillet to spread batter out in a thin layer. Cook until the top of the cr√™pe is no longer wet and the bottom has turned light brown, 1 to 2 minutes. Shake the pan or loosen with a spatula; turn or flip it over and cook until other side has turned light brown, about 1 minute more. Repeat with remaining batter.

review.reviewBody: This recipe was as close as I could find to the recipe I remembered my French friend using and showing me years ago. She was a true french cook: threw everything in a bowl without measuring cups, just "about a cup of this, a couple eggs, cup and a half or so of milk, maybe some water, shake of salt, a little sugar...". My way of cooking for sure. This recipe came out quite close to what I remember her crepes being. I put in some vanilla to jazz it up, and used my biggest pan to twirl on. I would have liked to have gotten them a bit thinner, but next time I'll know. Very good and authentic crepes--thank you.

The video showed what appeared to be vanilla, but there is no mention of vanilla extract in the ingredients. Otherwise this recipe is very close to the one I've used for years (I've used 1 tsp extract - vanilla, almond, etc. depending upon filling).
Love it and totally recommend it. Delicious and less greasy. This is a keeper. Nutella in the inside and for decoration and lots of fruit(it feels like I‚Äôm eating healthy). Thank you so much.üíï

This is basically how I was taught by my mom to make crepes and she learned from my dads mom. They are from the island of Guernsey in the English Channel nut my dads side was French. The only thing different is my mom taught me the crepes had to be thinner than pictured, lacy like doilies. My grandma and mom always made alot of them. They were eaten with my grandmas recipe for French beef stew and doughboys (big round lumpy flour dumplings that were put in the stew. The plumped upon there and also helped thicken the stew.) Then with the remaining that weren‚Äôt used for dinner were used for dessert. My mom love butter and sprinkled sugar on hers I like raspberry preserves on mine. This gets made when ever I go to my kids homes to see my kids and grandkids. 1st request for me to make. Michelle (Barbe‚Äô) Fischer.

this is by far the easiest crepe recipe I've come across. I don't have a stand or hand mixer so I just throw everything in a blender, the batter came out perfect. when you pour in the batter, make sure is away from the heat, tilt the pan and try to make the batter distribute equally throughout the pan. It takes practice to be perfect. Also another key is your pan retains heat, and every stove is different. I found that for medium-high heat for my stove and pan combo was way too hot. I ended up started at medium heat, after maybe 4 crepes I had to turn the heat down to medium-low.
All around 5 stars recipe I'll be making it as a breakfast meal prep for the week. Happy cooking!

I've made this recipe about 15 times now and I even though my first few attempts weren't perfect, I have found it to be a perfect crepe recipe. To get it perfect I make a few changes to the process.
First I mix the eggs alone, then add the milk. I make sure the milk is room temperature, it always makes it better! 
Then I add in the rest of the ingredients. 
Once mixed, the batter gets better the longer it sits so if you have time try and leave it for at least 10/15mins.

The best recipe out of 5 I‚Äôve tried (all highly rated). As for the butter, it should be 2 TABLESPOONs, not 2 teaspoons. I also added vanilla and more sugar, to personal preference; I added about 1/4 teaspoon of each. The house also smells so good after that new comers will want crepes.

I made these, my first crepes ever, in a very old cast iron pan, and they worked like a dream. The first morning, we had crepes with spinach, mushroom and tomato filling with white cheddar sauce. The second morning, I made them smaller and slathered with them homemade plum butter, and the third morning, I had enough batter for only four small crepes, topped with the same spinach mixture as before. Great as-is for a sweet filling (I like a little more sugar - personal preference) (or to eat plain - SO good) To make it savory, I leave out the sugar, add parsley or other herbs then fill with ricotta cheese, prosciutto, bacon, ham, etc. VERY easy but as others mentioned, if you are having trouble it's most likely with the pan and the temp. I use a setting just below Medium on my gas range, a small pan which I mop with olive oil every 3-4 crepes and just keep rolling the pan until the batter sets - flip it when it loosens from the pan and cook the other side for just a few second - 'voila! Because we don‚Äôt do dairy, I use unsweetened almond milk and olive oil in place of butter and milk. Works fine. I don‚Äôt add sugar anymore because I usually pair my crepes with a mix of sweet and savory. The sugar way is fine too. 

This recipe has been the right mix of flour, egg and milk for me always. I am French and learned how to make crepes in France, but this is an easier recipe but still gives me the result I want. 
I like that you don‚Äôt have to wait on the batter either (I was taught to let it sit for an hour). I also store the batter and cook crepes up later with this recipe.
